grammar.title: Sanskrit Sound System
grammar.meaning: Sanskrit has 13 vowels and 33 consonants organized systematically
grammar.usage: Sounds are organized by point of pronunciation (uccārana-sthāna)

examples.sanskrit: स्वर: अ आ इ ई उ ऊ ऋ ए ऐ ओ औ
examples.romanization: svaraḥ: a ā i ī u ū ṛ e ai o au
examples.english: Vowels: a ā i ī u ū ṛ e ai o au

examples.sanskrit: व्यञ्जन: क ख ग घ ङ (कण्ठ्य)
examples.romanization: vyañjana: ka kha ga gha ṅa (kaṇṭhya)
examples.english: Consonants: ka kha ga gha ṅa (velar)

grammar.notes: Consonants organized in 5 rows (varga): velar, palatal, retroflex, dental, labial

grammar.title: Short and Long Vowels
grammar.meaning: Each simple vowel has short and long forms; long = 2x short duration
grammar.usage: अ/आ, इ/ई, उ/ऊ, ऋ/ॠ - compound vowels (ए ऐ ओ औ) are always long
grammar.notes: Length is phonemic - changes word meaning

grammar.title: Devanagari Script - Vowel Marks
grammar.meaning: Vowels written as independent letters or marks on consonants

examples.english: Consonant k + long ā vowel mark

examples.romanization: pa + u-mark = pu, pa + ū-mark = pū

grammar.notes: Every consonant has inherent 'a'; vowel marks modify this

grammar.title: Syllables (akṣara)
grammar.meaning: Syllables classified by weight for meter
grammar.usage: Light: short vowel alone. Heavy: long vowel OR short vowel + consonant(s)

examples.english: Each syllable has short vowel, no following consonant in syllable

grammar.notes: Important for poetry/chanting

grammar.title: Sandhi Basics
grammar.meaning: Adjacent sounds combine/change according to phonetic rules
grammar.usage: Word-internal and word-boundary sandhi
grammar.notes: Three types: vowel sandhi, visarga sandhi, consonant sandhi

grammar.title: Sentence Structure
grammar.meaning: Sanskrit typically follows SOV word order
grammar.usage: Flexible due to case system, but SOV is most common
grammar.notes: Verb typically last; subject first

grammar.title: Nominals (nāma/subanta)
grammar.meaning: Nouns, pronouns, adjectives inflect for 3 genders, 3 numbers, 8 cases
grammar.usage: 24 possible forms per noun stem (3×3×8, excluding vocative)
grammar.notes: Nominals = nouns + pronouns + adjectives (all inflect)

grammar.title: Three Genders (linga)
grammar.meaning: Every noun has inherent grammatical gender
grammar.usage: Adjectives must agree with noun's gender

examples.sanskrit: सुन्दरः बालकः (m), सुन्दरा बालिका (f), सुन्दरं पुष्पम् (n)
examples.romanization: sundaraḥ bālakaḥ, sundarā bālikā, sundaraṃ puṣpam
examples.english: Beautiful boy, beautiful girl, beautiful flower

grammar.notes: Gender not always predictable from meaning

grammar.title: Three Numbers (vacana)
grammar.meaning: Sanskrit distinguishes singular, dual (two), and plural (3+)
grammar.usage: Nominals and verbs inflect for all three numbers
grammar.notes: Dual is unique feature, rarely found in modern languages

grammar.title: Eight Cases (vibhakti) - Overview
grammar.meaning: 8 cases: nominative, accusative, instrumental, dative, ablative, genitive, locative, vocative
grammar.usage: Case indicates noun's role in sentence
grammar.notes: Case system allows flexible word order

grammar.title: Nominative Case (prathamā vibhakti)
grammar.meaning: Marks the subject/agent (kartṛ) of action
grammar.usage: Also used for predicate nominatives
grammar.notes: First case (prathamā); answers 'who/what?'

grammar.title: Accusative Case (dvitīyā vibhakti)
grammar.meaning: Marks the direct object (karman) of action
grammar.usage: Also used for destination and duration

examples.english: The boy reads a book. (book = object)

grammar.notes: Second case (dvitīyā); answers 'whom/what?'

grammar.title: Verbs (dhātu/tiṅanta) - Basics
grammar.meaning: Verbs inflect for tense, mood, voice, person, number
grammar.usage: 10 verb classes (gaṇa), 6 tense-moods, 2 voices (pada)

examples.english: Read → he reads, they-two read, they read

grammar.notes: Verb endings (tiṅ) contain person+number information

grammar.title: Present Tense (laṭ lakāra)
grammar.meaning: Describes present actions/states
grammar.usage: Most common tense; uses special tense-mood formations

examples.english: I am, you are, he/she is
I go, you go, he/she goes

grammar.notes: Present indicative (vartamāna); bhū class most common for beginners

grammar.title: Three Persons (puruṣa)
grammar.meaning: Verbs agree with subject's person
grammar.usage: Each person × 3 numbers = 9 forms per tense

examples.sanskrit: अहं पठामि (1st), त्वं पठसि (2nd), सः पठति (3rd)
examples.romanization: ahaṃ paṭhāmi, tvaṃ paṭhasi, saḥ paṭhati
examples.english: I read, you read, he/she reads

grammar.notes: Third person (prathama) used for pronouns and nouns

grammar.title: Parasmaipada vs Ātmanepada
grammar.meaning: Two sets of verb endings based on voice
grammar.usage: Parasmaipada for action benefiting others; ātmanepada for self
grammar.notes: Some roots use only one voice; some use both (ubhayapada)

grammar.title: Uninflected Words (avyaya)
grammar.meaning: Includes adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, particles
grammar.usage: No gender/number/case inflection

examples.sanskrit: रामः च सीता च (Rama and Sita)

grammar.notes: Very common in connecting ideas and phrases

grammar.title: Prefixes (upasarga)
grammar.meaning: 20 standard prefixes that attach to verb roots
grammar.usage: Change or intensify verb meaning

examples.sanskrit: गम् (go) → आगम् (come), प्रगम् (go forth), निर्गम् (go out)

examples.english: Prefix आ reverses गम् (go) to mean come

grammar.notes: Prefixes undergo sandhi with root; crucial for verb meanings

grammar.title: Agreement (samanvaya)
grammar.pattern: Adjectives agree with nouns; verbs agree with subjects
grammar.meaning: Grammatical features must match
grammar.usage: Adjectives: gender+number+case; Verbs: person+number
grammar.notes: Critical for correct Sanskrit; check all agreements

grammar.title: Verbless Sentences
grammar.meaning: Sanskrit often omits 'to be' in present tense
grammar.usage: Copula (अस्ति) can be dropped
grammar.notes: Very common; both nominals in same case (usually nominative)

practice.question: Which is the long form of अ?
practice.explanation: आ is the long (dīrgha) form of अ, held for two beats (mātrā)

practice.question: How many basic vowels does Sanskrit have?
practice.explanation: Sanskrit has 13 vowels: अ आ इ ई उ ऊ ऋ ॠ ऌ ॡ ए ऐ ओ औ (including rare ऌ ॡ)

practice.question: Which consonant is the velar nasal?
practice.explanation: ङ (ṅa) is the velar nasal, pronounced like 'ng' in 'sing'

practice.question: What is the point of pronunciation for 'त' (ta)?
practice.explanation: त is a dental (danta) consonant - tongue touches the teeth

practice.question: Which are the three sibilants (ūṣman) in Sanskrit?
practice.explanation: The three sibilants are श (śa - palatal), ष (ṣa - retroflex), स (sa - dental)

practice.question: What is the typical word order in Sanskrit?
practice.explanation: Sanskrit typically follows SOV order: बालकः पुस्तकं पठति (boy book reads)

practice.question: How many genders (linga) does Sanskrit have?
practice.explanation: Sanskrit has 3 genders: Masculine (puṃlinga), Feminine (strīlinga), Neuter (napuṃsakalinga)

practice.question: How many cases (vibhakti) are there in Sanskrit?
practice.explanation: Sanskrit has 8 cases: nominative, accusative, instrumental, dative, ablative, genitive, locative, vocative

practice.question: What is unique about Sanskrit's number system compared to English?
options: It has singular and plural only
It has singular, dual, and plural
practice.correctAnswer: It has singular, dual, and plural
practice.explanation: Sanskrit has three numbers (vacana): singular (ekavacana), dual (dvivacana) for exactly two, and plural (bahuvacana) for three or more

practice.question: Which case is used for the subject of a sentence?
practice.explanation: The nominative case (prathamā vibhakti) marks the subject (kartṛ) of the sentence

practice.question: What does 'नमस्ते' (namaste) mean?
practice.explanation: नमस्ते (namaste) is the traditional Sanskrit greeting meaning 'salutations to you'

practice.question: What is the Sanskrit word for 'water'?
practice.explanation: जलम् (jalam) means water; it's a neuter -a stem noun

practice.question: What does the verb root 'गम्' (gam) mean?
practice.explanation: गम् (gam) means 'to go'; it becomes गच्छति (gacchati) in present tense

practice.question: What is the first person singular pronoun in Sanskrit?
practice.explanation: अहम् (aham) means 'I' - first person singular pronoun from asmad declension

practice.question: What gender is the noun 'बालकः' (bālakaḥ - boy)?
practice.explanation: बालकः is masculine (puṃlinga), -a stem noun meaning 'boy'

practice.question: Translate: बालकः पुस्तकं पठति
practice.explanation: बालकः (boy, nom.) पुस्तकं (book, acc.) पठति (reads) = 'The boy reads a book' (SOV order)

reading.title: First Words
reading.english: Greetings. I am Rama. Who are you?
reading.grammar_notes: Verbless sentences: 'अहं रामः' = 'I [am] Rama' - copula omitted

reading.title: Simple Action
reading.sanskrit: बालकः गृहं गच्छति। सा पुस्तकं पठति।
reading.romanization: bālakaḥ gṛhaṃ gacchati. sā pustakaṃ paṭhati.
reading.english: The boy goes home. She reads a book.
reading.grammar_notes: SOV word order. Accusative case for destination (गृहं) and direct object (पुस्तकं)

reading.title: Nature
reading.sanskrit: वृक्षः उच्चः। पुष्पं सुन्दरम्। जलं शीतलम्।
reading.romanization: vṛkṣaḥ uccaḥ. puṣpaṃ sundaram. jalaṃ śītalam.
reading.english: The tree is tall. The flower is beautiful. The water is cold.
reading.grammar_notes: Verbless sentences with adjectives. Adjectives agree with nouns in gender (m/n), number (sg), case (nom)

comprehensionQuestions.question: What quality is attributed to the tree?

reading.question: What does 'नमस्ते' mean?
reading.explanation: नमस्ते (namaste) is the traditional Sanskrit greeting meaning 'I bow to you'

reading.question: What does 'अहम्' mean?
reading.explanation: अहम् (aham) is the first person pronoun meaning 'I'

reading.question: What does 'गच्छामि' mean?
reading.explanation: गच्छामि (gacchāmi) means 'I go' - first person singular present tense of √गम्

reading.question: What does 'पठामि' mean?
reading.explanation: पठामि (paṭhāmi) means 'I read' - from the root √पठ्

reading.question: What does 'एकम्' mean?
reading.explanation: एकम् (ekam) is the number 'one' in Sanskrit
